Here is the absolute ranking (1 = best overall, 8 = worst), considering resolution, refresh rate, panel quality, connectivity, and general versatility:

1. Dell UltraSharp U2723QE – 27", 4K IPS, USB‑C hub, pro‑grade color/ergonomics (best all‑rounder for productivity + creation).  
2. MSI Optix MAG274QRF‑QD – 27", 1440p, 165Hz Rapid IPS, Quantum Dot, G‑SYNC compatible (excellent balance of gaming + image quality).  
3. ASUS ROG Swift PG259QN – 24.5", 1080p, 360Hz IPS, NVIDIA Reflex (absolute top‑tier esports, but niche and only 1080p).  
4. Acer Nitro XV272U RV – 27", 1440p, high‑refresh IPS gaming monitor (strong gaming value, slightly below MSI’s feature set).  
5. Philips 346B1C – 34", 3440×1440 curved ultrawide with USB‑C docking (great for productivity/immersion, but lower refresh and slower panel).  
6. LG 27GN750‑B – 27", 1080p, 240Hz IPS (good esports‑focused FHD, but outclassed by 1440p and 4K options).  
7. AOC C32G2E – 32", 1080p, 165Hz VA curved (large and immersive but very low pixel density; VA trade‑offs).  
8. ViewSonic TD2455 – 24", 1080p touch, USB‑C (very niche business/interactive use; weakest as a “general” monitor).
